competitive_intel:
## Available Competitive Intelligence

- Competition description: `../research/description.md`
- 5 top kernel notebooks in `../research/kernels/`

data_findings.finding: This is a 2D polygon packing problem: pack Christmas tree-shaped polygons (15 vertices) into smallest square bounding box for N=1 to 200 trees. Score = sum of (side_length^2 / N) for all N. Target score: 68.894234. Trees have specific shape with trunk, 3 tiers. Key approaches from kernels: 1) Greedy placement with collision detection using Shapely STRtree, 2) Simulated Annealing (bbox3 binary), 3) Shake optimization (shake_public binary), 4) fix_direction - rotation optimization to minimize bounding box, 5) Overlap validation and repair.

Key techniques from kernels: 1) ChristmasTree class with Decimal precision for coordinates, 2) Shapely for polygon operations and collision detection, 3) ConvexHull + minimize_scalar for optimal rotation angle, 4) Multi-phase optimization: short runs to find promising (n,r) params, then longer runs on best candidates, 5) Overlap repair by replacing invalid groups with donor solutions.

From snapshots: Best achieved score is 70.647306 (target: 68.894234, gap: 1.75 points). Key approaches tried: 1) SA with fractional translation (jonathanchan), 2) bbox3 optimizer, 3) tree_packer_v18/v21, 4) Backward propagation, 5) Ensemble from 30 CSV files. All failed to improve beyond 70.647306. The solution is at a very tight local optimum. CRITICAL: Tessellation approach (egortrushin) for large N not fully implemented - uses 2 base trees translated in grid pattern.

Academic research on 2D irregular polygon packing: 1) No-fit polygon (NFP) for O(1) overlap checks, 2) Local search heuristics (Jostle algorithm), 3) Genetic algorithms with unrestricted rotation, 4) Extended local search with nonlinear programming, 5) Simulated annealing + linear programming hybrids, 6) Bottom-left heuristics with tabu search. Key insight: Hybrid approaches combining heuristics with metaheuristics perform best.

web_research.query: What are the best algorithms for 2D irregular polygon packing optimization problems?
web_research.finding:
Los algoritmos más efectivos para resolver problemas de optimización de empaquetamiento de polígonos irregulares en 2D incluyen enfoques heurísticos, metaheurísticos y algoritmos exactos. Entre los heurísticos, el método de búsqueda local ha demostrado ser muy eficiente, especialmente cuando se combina con algoritmos genéticos, ya que puede gestionar decisiones complejas como la orientación y la colocación de las piezas sin restricciones artificiales ([Abeysooriya et al., 2017](https://eprints.soton.ac.uk/415314)). Además, el algoritmo de Jostle, que es un método heurístico, ha sido utilizado para mejorar la eficiencia en estos problemas ([Abeysooriya et al., 2017](https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-68496)). 

Por otro lado, los algoritmos exactos y las estrategias de metaheurísticas como la búsqueda en vecindad extendida basadas en programación no lineal también han sido explorados para estos problemas, logrando resultados de alta calidad en casos complejos ([Gomes, 2012](https://www.s
